snippet: Documents obtained by an advocacy group question the handling of animals used in the production of the canceled series “Luck.”
abstract: HBO comes under renewed scrutiny for the treatment of horses on Luck, its recently canceled dramatic series set in the world of gambling and horse racing; documents obtained by advocacy group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals once again question the handling of animals used in the series and the qualifications of professionals charged with looking after them. (M)
lead_paragraph: HBO has come under renewed scrutiny for the treatment of horses on ''Luck,'' its recently canceled dramatic series set in the world of gambling and horse racing, as documents obtained by an advocacy group once again questioned the handling of animals used in the series and the qualifications of professionals charged with looking after them. HBO ended production on ''Luck,'' a low-rated series produced by David Milch and Michael Mann and starring Dustin Hoffman, in March, following revelations that three horses were euthanized after being injured during work at the Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif.
